citations.narrative:
During the inspection, three Cavalier puppies, less than 16 weeks of age, were not identified on any required USDA
records. Although the puppies were microchipped, their identification was not documented on a cage card or a USDA
7005 form. These records are essential for identifying dogs and tracking their movements. Each dealer must make, keep,
and maintain records that fully and accurately disclose the date and description of acquisitions, including any offspring
born of any animal while in the licensee’s possession or under their control.

The puppy and adult vaccination schedule in the program of veterinary care (PVC) was incomplete and not being
followed. According to the PVC, vaccinations for parvovirus and distemper are to be administered at 6 and 8 weeks, with
no further doses noted beyond 8 weeks of age. Rabies vaccinations are indicated at 12 weeks, annually and then every
three years.
The licensee administered two parvovirus vaccinations along with one distemper vaccine to the adults in 2023 with no
follow-up does. The licensee is currently administering parvo vaccines to puppies at 4, 5, and 6 weeks, and distemper at 5
weeks. However, no further doses are documented beyond that. There are also five 16-week-old Dachshund puppies that
have not received a rabies vaccination.
Failure to maintain a complete vaccination schedule, and failure to follow the schedule as directed by the attending
veterinarian (AV), increases the risk of preventable disease, infection, and undue pain and suffering. The licensee must
work with the AV to ensure a complete and accurate vaccination schedule is developed and followed, in accordance with
the PVC and AC guidance for the prevention of contagious and/or deadly diseases.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by June 20, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.75(a) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors 
During the inspection, three Cavalier puppies, less than 16 weeks of age, were not identified on any required USDA 
records. Although the puppies were microchipped, their identification was not documented on a cage card or a USDA 
7005 form. These records are essential for identifying dogs and tracking their movements. Each dealer must make, keep, 
and maintain records that fully and accurately disclose the date and description of acquisitions, including any offspring 
born of any animal while in the licensee’s possession or under their control. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The puppy and adult vaccination schedule in the program of veterinary care (PVC) was incomplete and not being 
followed. According to the PVC, vaccinations for parvovirus and distemper are to be administered at 6 and 8 weeks, with 
no further doses noted beyond 8 weeks of age. Rabies vaccinations are indicated at 12 weeks, annually and then every 
three years. 
 
The licensee administered two parvovirus vaccinations along with one distemper vaccine to the adults in 2023 with no 
follow-up does. The licensee is currently administering parvo vaccines to puppies at 4, 5, and 6 weeks, and distemper at 5 
weeks. However, no further doses are documented beyond that. There are also five 16-week-old Dachshund puppies that 
have not received a rabies vaccination.  
 
Failure to maintain a complete vaccination schedule, and failure to follow the schedule as directed by the attending 
veterinarian (AV), increases the risk of preventable disease, infection, and undue pain and suffering. The licensee must 
work with the AV to ensure a complete and accurate vaccination schedule is developed and followed, in accordance with 
the PVC and AC guidance for the prevention of contagious and/or deadly diseases. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by June 20, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.

Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
